issue.title: Build failure on OpenBSD
issue.body:
> Which operating system does the issue occur on?

OpenBSD 6.5-current

> Problem

`nix:0.12.0` does not compile on OpenBSD. `nix:0.13.0` should, I believe. I tried to force `alacritty` to use the latter but `wayland-client` keeps pulling down the dependency to `0.12.0`. This is probably a layman question, but would there be a way to globally pin `nix` or configure `alacritty` to skip the `wayland-client` dependency, useless on OpenBSD?

Thanks !

body:
Based on some research it seems like support for BSD on the popular CI platforms like Travis is very limited. The only online CI service I found which provides BSD support seems to be [cirrus](https://cirrus-ci.org/guide/FreeBSD).

One alternative would be to setup a custom build environment just for BSD, though this would likely be a lot of effort for a poorly integrated version.

Don't know if you'd be interested in https://builds.sr.ht/ which does support FreeBSD among others. I actually haven't used it myself but the people behind https://github.com/swaywm/sway are also behind sr.ht.

I wasn't aware that sr.ht also supports BSD. Based on that info alone I'd say it's probably the most promising platform I've seen so far.

However there's quite a barrier of entry for it, since it requires monthly payments. For projects that are completely on sourcehut that might not be a problem but just for testing out the CI process might not be worth it especially since I'm not sure how well Rust would be supported.

I'm surprised to see that there's github integration though. I was about to note that as another potential point of trouble but then saw on the sway github repo that it seems to be just working like travis or similar.

So while I'm not going to rush into setting up sourcehut to run all of Alacritty's CI at this point, I'll definitely keep it in mind. It seems like one of the better options available for BSD CI, so thanks for bringing it up.
Hey, I'd be happy to give alacritty free builds on sourcehut.

@ddevault That's a very nice offer and I'd love to take you up on that. At least for the period of setting everything up and testing the platform out, it would help a lot not to pay out of pocket for something that might not even pan out right in the end.

However, sourcehut is hardly asking for much (starting with $2/month) and also has development and hosting/electricity to pay for. So if we should decide to go with sourcehut for the future of at least BSD builds, I'd like to pay for the services we use rather than taking advantage of having reasonable popularity (which would be unfair to other, smaller projects imo). Chances are Alacritty would also be able to come up with at least the minimum price of sourcehut by taking donations itself, though I'd have to look into that and it would probably take a bit of effort to setup.
I use Alacritty as my daily driver, this would be an easy way to thank you for it :)

That's lovely to hear and does make for an exchange I'd be very happy about.

Since payment is currently optional as far as I can tell, it should also be possible to just try things out and see how it goes. So I think this is definitely the way forward for automatic BSD builds, especially since I'm not aware of any reasonable alternative. I'll have a play around with it this weekend to see how things pan out.

Thanks for the support @ddevault.
No problem. I just upgraded you to a lifetime free account on sr.ht, enjoy!

issue.title: [WIP] Preliminary efforts to add *BSD CI
issue.body:
Closes #2248.

---

This is a draft for adding *BSD support to our CI, utilizing the [https://builds.sr.ht](https://builds.sr.ht) and [https://dispatch.sr.ht](https://dispatch.sr.ht) services.

As it is, there are a few problems with this (or rather, differences from Travis):
- [ ] sequential execution of tasks (all subsequent tasks are blocked until completion)
- [ ] lack of ability to restart a single, failed task
- [ ] no way to specify allowed-failures (like we do with all nightly builds under Travis)
  - I currently `|| true` all tests that would be an allowed-failure, which works but isn't as graceful, nor notifies when it fails
- [ ] dispatch.sr.ht requires full access (r/w) to all repos in order to set up the webhook (see also: https://todo.sr.ht/~sircmpwn/dispatch.sr.ht/22)
  - could maybe be worked around if dispatch.sr.ht were to provide a way to manually create a webhook?

In regards to points 1 and 2, we could just split every single task into its own file. I haven't tested if having subfolders in `.builds` would succeed, which could allow us to keep the folder from getting too hectic if we decide to move our other targets to sr.ht as well. This would also allow us to restart single tasks as well as have them all run in parallel.

---

(the following are notes and not necessarily blockers)

### FreeBSD
My current implementation uses `rustup` to install v1.36.0, stable, and nightly Rust toolchains. We could potentially drop 1.36.0 in favor of using Rust stable straight from FreeBSD's ports. This would also cull nightly, because neither package installs `rustup` for managing versions.

Example build for the curious: https://builds.sr.ht/~cole_h/job/114951

### OpenBSD
OpenBSD is a Tier 3 target for Rust, which results in no `rustup` being built for it (available from rustup.rs, at least). This means we can only CI the available version, which at the time of writing is 1.38.0.

Example build for the curious: https://builds.sr.ht/~cole_h/job/114979
